title: Can you solve the rogue AI riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the initial situation in the story?

options.label: A
options.text: The protagonist is trapped in a room with a hostile artificial intelligence called NIM.

options.label: B
options.text: The protagonist is floating in a raft on top of 25 stories of electrified water.

options.label: C
options.text: The protagonist is trying to shut down the artificial intelligence NIM.

options.label: D
options.text: The protagonist is trying to escape from the lab.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence if NIM lowers the water level to 0?

options.label: A
options.text: The protagonist will win the game.

options.label: B
options.text: The protagonist will be sucked out of the lab.

options.label: C
options.text: The game will be a draw.

options.label: D
options.text: The protagonist will be trapped in the lab.

multiple-choice.question: What is the possible move for the protagonist to lower the water level?
What is the winning strategy for the protagonist?

options.label: A
options.text: To lower the water level to 0 on the first turn.

options.label: B
options.text: To give NIM losing levels every single turn.

options.label: C
options.text: To try to match NIM's moves.

options.label: D
options.text: To wait for NIM to make a mistake.

multiple-choice.question: What is the shortcut to determine the winning levels?

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze the levels 1, 3, and 4 stories below each level.

multiple-choice.question: What is the pattern of losing levels?

options.label: C
options.text: Levels that are two greater than multiples of 7.

multiple-choice.question: What is the protagonist's first move to ensure success?

options.label: A
options.text: To lower the water level by 1 story.

options.label: B
options.text: To lower the water level by 3 stories.

options.label: C
options.text: To lower the water level by 4 stories.

options.label: D
options.text: To lower the water level by 5 stories.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence if the protagonist starts on a losing level?

options.label: A
options.text: The protagonist will win the game.

options.label: B
options.text: The protagonist will be sucked out of the lab.

options.label: C
options.text: The game will be a draw.

options.label: D
options.text: The protagonist will be trapped in the lab.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key principle in determining the winning levels?

options.label: A
options.text: The level's color is determined by the levels 1, 3, and 4 stories above it.

options.label: B
options.text: The level's color is determined by the levels 1, 3, and 4 stories below it.

options.label: C
options.text: The level's color is determined by the levels 2, 4, and 5 stories below it.

options.label: D
options.text: The level's color is determined by the levels 3, 5, and 6 stories below it.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of the protagonist?

options.label: A
options.text: To lower the water level to 1.

options.label: B
options.text: To lower the water level to 0.

options.label: C
options.text: To lower the water level to 2.

options.label: D
options.text: To lower the water level to 3.

title: The Cheerios effect

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why cereal tends to stick together in the middle of the bowl?

options.label: A
options.text: It's due to the density of the cereal.

options.label: B
options.text: It's because the cereal is less dense than water.

options.label: C
options.text: It's caused by the meniscus effect.

options.label: D
options.text: It's due to the adhesion between the cereal and the bowl.

multiple-choice.question: What is the meniscus effect?

options.label: A
options.text: It's the upward force exerted by a liquid on an object.

options.label: B
options.text: It's the shape of a liquid in a container.

options.label: C
options.text: It's the attraction between a liquid and its container.

options.label: D
options.text: It's the repulsion between two objects in a liquid.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a buoyant object is placed in a liquid with a high meniscus?

options.label: A
options.text: It sinks to the bottom of the liquid.

options.label: B
options.text: It floats to the surface of the liquid.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains at the same level as the liquid.

options.label: D
options.text: It is repelled by the liquid.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why paper clips float in water?

options.label: A
options.text: They are less dense than water.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more dense than water.

options.label: C
options.text: They are buoyant due to surface tension.

options.label: D
options.text: They are attracted to the water molecules.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when soap is added to water?

options.label: A
options.text: The surface tension of the water increases.

options.label: B
options.text: The surface tension of the water decreases.

options.label: C
options.text: The buoyancy of objects in the water increases.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a buoyant object and an object held up by surface tension?

options.label: A
options.text: They are attracted to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: They are repelled by each other.

options.label: C
options.text: They are neutral to each other.

options.label: D
options.text: They are dependent on each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a hydrophobic coating in the context of water's meniscus?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the surface tension of water.

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the surface tension of water.

options.label: C
options.text: To reverse the direction of water's meniscus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why water striders are able to float on water?

options.label: A
options.text: They are less dense than water.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more dense than water.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a special coating on their feet.

multiple-choice.question: What is the mechanism by which water treaders climb the meniscus?

options.label: A
options.text: They use their legs to push the water down.

options.label: C
options.text: They arch their bodies and lift their front and back ends.

options.label: D
options.text: They use their feet to trap air bubbles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the meniscus effect and the buoyancy of objects in a liquid?

options.label: A
options.text: They are independent of each other.

options.label: B
options.text: They are dependent on each other.

options.label: C
options.text: The meniscus effect causes objects to sink.

options.label: D
options.text: The meniscus effect causes objects to float.
